title: A vending machine dispensing products
content: Which analogy best describes the Mediator Pattern?
explanation: The correct answer is: An air traffic controller guiding planes so they don't talk to each other directly

options.text: A librarian managing which books readers can borrow
An air traffic controller guiding planes so they don't talk to each other directly

title: Provides a single point of communication
content: Which of the following are advantages of using the Mediator Pattern?
explanation: The correct answer is: Reduces coupling between components

options.text: Provides a single point of communication

title: Request has test header: undefined
explanation: The correct answer is: Request has test header: true

title: This is a common misconception. The correct answer is different.
content: How does the Mediator Pattern differ from the Observer Pattern?
explanation: Observer Pattern is event-driven, where subscribers listen to changes. Mediator centralizes interactions by routing communication between participants. Mediator reduces direct object references, Observer reduces direct polling.

options.text: Observer Pattern is event-driven, where subscribers listen to changes. Mediator centralizes interactions by routing communication between participants.
options.explanation: Observer Pattern is event-driven, where subscribers listen to changes. Mediator centralizes interactions by routing communication between participants. Mediator reduces direct object references, Observer reduces direct polling.

options.text: This is not correct. Please refer to the explanation.
Incorrect. Review the design pattern concepts.
This is a common misconception. The correct answer is different.

title: backwards only works with JavaScript
content: Animation fill modes control element state before/after animation. Explain the different fill modes.
explanation: none: no styles before/after. forwards: keeps final keyframe styles after animation. backwards: applies first keyframe styles before delay. both: forwards + backwards. Useful for maintaining animation end state or starting state during delay.

options.text: forwards: keep final styles; backwards: apply first styles during delay; both: combine both
options.explanation: Correct. fill-mode controls pre/post animation styles.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: All properties have equal performance
content: Animation performance matters for smooth UX. Identify properties that impact animation performance.
explanation: Properties: transform and opacity are GPU-accelerated (best). width, height, margin, padding trigger layout (slow). background-color triggers paint (medium). Use transform/opacity when possible. Avoid animating layout-triggering properties.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with JavaScript
content: Transform origin controls the point around which transformations occur. Explain its purpose and usage.
explanation: transform-origin sets the point for transform operations (rotate, scale, skew). Default: center (50% 50%). Can be keywords (top, left, center) or coordinates. Affects where element rotates/scales from. Essential for natural-looking animations.

options.text: Sets the point for transform operations (rotate/scale); default is center

options.explanation: Incorrect. It controls transformation point, not speed.
Incorrect. transform-origin is a standard property.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: All properties should always be animated separately
content: Grouping animated properties affects performance. Identify best practices for property grouping.
explanation: Group GPU-accelerated properties (transform, opacity) together. Avoid mixing layout properties (width, margin) with transform. Animate transform properties together (translate, rotate, scale). Keep animations on same composite layer.

options.explanation: Correct. Transform properties work well together.

options.text: width with transform (mixing layout and composite)
options.explanation: Incorrect. Mixing layout and composite hurts performance.

options.text: All properties should always be animated separately
options.explanation: Incorrect. Grouping compatible properties is better.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: animation only works with JavaScript
content: CSS provides two animation mechanisms. Explain transitions vs animations and their use cases.
explanation: transition: simple state changes (hover, focus), single property changes, triggered by state. animation: complex multi-step animations, keyframe-based, can loop/reverse, more control. Use transition for simple changes, animation for complex sequences.

options.text: transition: simple state changes; animation: complex keyframe sequences
options.explanation: Correct. Transitions are simpler, animations more powerful.
Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.
Incorrect. CSS animations are pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works on mobile devices
content: Accessibility requires respecting user motion preferences. Explain prefers-reduced-motion and implementation.
explanation: prefers-reduced-motion: user prefers less animation (accessibility setting). Should disable or reduce animations. Use <cod@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) to disable animations. Essential for accessibility, prevents motion sickness, respects user choice.

options.text: Detects user preference for reduced motion; should disable/reduce animations for accessibility

options.explanation: Incorrect. It detects preference to reduce motion.
Incorrect. Works on all devices with the setting.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: color (animatable)
content: Not all CSS properties are animatable. Identify which properties can be animated smoothly.
explanation: Animatable: transform, opacity, color, background-color, width, height, margin, padding, border-radius, etc. Non-animatable: display, position (static/relative/absolute), font-family, z-index (discrete). Transform and opacity are most performant (GPU-accelerated).

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with JavaScript
content: Timing functions control animation speed curves. Explain different timing functions and their effects.
explanation: Timing function controls speed curve: ease (slow-fast-slow, default), linear (constant speed), ease-in (slow start), ease-out (slow end), ease-in-out (slow both ends), cubic-bezier() (custom curve). Creates natural-feeling motion.

options.text: Controls animation speed curve; ease: slow-fast-slow; linear: constant; cubic-bezier: custom
options.explanation: Correct. Timing functions create motion curves.
Incorrect. They create different motion feels.
Incorrect. Timing functions are pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: transform only works with JavaScript
content: Positioning animations can be done multiple ways. Explain why transform is preferred over position properties.
explanation: transform: translate() uses GPU, doesn't trigger layout, smoother. left/top: triggers layout recalculation, repaint, slower. Transform is composited on GPU layer. Position properties cause reflow. Always prefer transform for animations.

options.text: transform: GPU-accelerated, no layout; left/top: triggers layout, slower
options.explanation: Correct. transform is much more performant.
Incorrect. transform is preferred for animations.
Incorrect. CSS transform is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Prevents animations from running
content: Performance optimization for animations. Explain will-change and best practices for usage.
explanation: will-change hints browser about upcoming changes, enables optimization (GPU layer promotion). Use sparingly: only when animation is about to start, remove after. Overuse causes memory issues. Better to use only when needed, not preemptively.

options.text: Hints browser about upcoming changes for optimization; use sparingly, remove after animation
options.explanation: Correct. will-change should be used carefully.

options.text: Should be applied to all animated elements

options.explanation: Incorrect. Most animations work fine without it.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Utility-first CSS uses utility classes. Explain the approach, benefits, and when to use it.
explanation: Utility-first: small utility classes (e<cod.g., <cod.text-center, <cod.p-4). Advantages: rapid development, consistent design, small bundle (with purging). Trade-offs: HTML verbosity, learning curve, less semantic.

options.text: Small utility classes; rapid development; consistent design; trade-off: HTML verbosity

options.explanation: Incorrect. Concept applies to any utility framework.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Critical CSS is above-the-fold CSS. Explain critical CSS extraction and its impact on FCP.
explanation: Critical CSS: styles needed for above-the-fold content. Inline in <head, load rest asynchronously. Improves FCP by reducing render-blocking CSS. Extract with tools, inline manually, or use loadCSS.

options.text: Above-the-fold CSS; inline in <head; improves FCP by reducing render-blocking
options.explanation: Correct. Critical CSS improves initial render.
Incorrect. It speeds up initial render.
Incorrect. Critical CSS is best practice.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Font display controls font loading behavior. Explain font-display values and their impact on performance.
explanation: font-display: auto (browser default), block (<cod3s block, infinite swap), swap (immediate swap), fallback (<cod100ms block, <cod3s swap), optional (<cod100ms block, no swap). Controls FOIT/FOUT, affects CLS.

options.text: Controls font loading: block/swap/fallback/optional; affects FOIT/FOUT and CLS

options.explanation: Incorrect. font-display is essential for performance.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: BEM is a CSS naming methodology. Explain Block__Element<cod--Modifier structure and its benefits.
explanation: BEM: Block (component), Element (part of block), Modifier (variant). Syntax: <cod.block__element--modifier. Benefits: prevents conflicts, clear structure, no nesting needed, self-documenting.

options.text: Block__Element<cod--Modifier; prevents conflicts; clear structure; self-documenting

options.explanation: Incorrect. BEM can use any selector.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which PostCSS features enable modern CSS syntax in older browsers? (Select all that apply)
content: PostCSS can transform modern CSS. Identify features that enable modern syntax support.
explanation: postcss-preset-env: enables modern CSS (custom properties, nesting, etc.). autoprefixer: adds vendor prefixes. cssnano: minifies. These enable modern syntax with fallbacks.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which CSS loading strategies improve performance? (Select all that apply)
content: CSS loading affects performance. Identify strategies that optimize CSS delivery.
explanation: Strategies: media attribute (load conditionally), preload (hint browser), async loading, critical CSS inline, split CSS files, remove unused CSS. All improve performance.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: CSS Modules provide scoped CSS. Explain how CSS Modules work and solve global scope issues.
explanation: CSS Modules: locally scoped classes, generated unique class names, imported as objects. Solves global scope pollution, enables component-scoped styles. Works with build tools (Webpack, Vite).

options.text: Locally scoped classes; unique names; imported as objects; solves global scope issues

options.explanation: Incorrect. CSS Modules are widely used.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Content visibility enables lazy rendering. Explain content-visibility and its performance benefits for long pages.
explanation: content-visibility: auto (skips rendering until needed), hidden (skips rendering), visible (normal). Enables virtual scrolling, improves initial render. Browser skips layout/paint for off-screen content. Use for long lists, feeds.

options.text: Skips rendering off-screen content; improves initial load; enables virtual scrolling

options.explanation: Incorrect. content-visibility is a modern feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: JavaScript can control CSS animations. Explain how to synchronize and control animations programmatically.
explanation: Use animation events: animationstart, animationend, animationiteration. Access via element<cod.ontransitionend or addEventListener. Can pause/resume with animation-play-state. Use requestAnimationFrame for synchronization.

options.text: Use animation events (animationstart/end/iteration); control with animation-play-state; sync with requestAnimationFrame

options.explanation: Incorrect. Works with CSS classes too.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Animation direction controls how keyframes are played. Explain direction values and their effects.
explanation: animation-direction: normal (forward), reverse (backward), alternate (forward then reverse), alternate-reverse (reverse then forward). Controls keyframe sequence playback direction.

options.text: normal: forward; reverse: backward; alternate: forward/reverse; alternate-reverse: reverse/forward
options.explanation: Correct. Each value controls playback direction.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Are deprecated
content: Design tokens standardize design values. Explain CSS custom properties as design tokens and their benefits.
explanation: Design tokens: standardized design values (colors, spacing, typography). CSS custom properties enable tokens. Benefits: single source of truth, easy theming, consistency, maintainability. Use for colors, spacing, typography scales.

options.text: Standardized design values; single source of truth; enables theming and consistency

options.explanation: Incorrect. Tokens can be any design value.
Incorrect. CSS custom properties work without JS.
Incorrect. Design tokens are modern best practice.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: ITCSS is a CSS architecture methodology. Explain the inverted triangle structure and how it organizes CSS.
explanation: ITCSS layers (bottom to top): Settings (variables), Tools (mixins), Generic (resets), Elements (base styles), Objects (layout), Components (UI), Utilities (helpers). Organizes CSS by specificity and reach. Prevents specificity conflicts.

options.text: Layers: Settings  Tools  Generic  Elements  Objects  Components  Utilities; organizes by specificity

options.explanation: Incorrect. Utilities are at the top.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Both are deprecated
content: SASS <cod@use is modern replacement for <cod@import. Explain differences and migration considerations.
explanation: <cod@use: modern module system, namespaced, loaded once. <cod@import: legacy, global scope, can cause duplicates. <cod@use prevents conflicts, better performance. Migrate from <cod@import to <cod@use for new code.

options.text: <cod@use: modern, namespaced, loaded once; <cod@import: legacy, global, can duplicate; prefer @use

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Timing functions control animation speed curves. Explain timing functions and their visual effects.
explanation: Timing functions: ease (default), linear (constant), ease-in (slow start), ease-out (slow end), ease-in-out (slow start/end), cubic-bezier (custom curve), steps (discrete steps). Controls acceleration/deceleration.

options.text: Controls speed curve: ease, linear, ease-in, ease-out, ease-in-out, cubic-bezier, steps
options.explanation: Correct. Timing functions control animation curve.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which CSS architecture methodologies emphasize component-based organization? (Select all that apply)
content: Component-based CSS organization is common. Identify methodologies that focus on component structure.
explanation: Component-based: BEM (Block Element Modifier), CSS Modules, Styled Components, CSS-in-JS. These organize CSS around components rather than pages. Better for component libraries, React/Vue apps.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Are deprecated
content: SASS partials enable modular CSS. Explain partials, <cod@import, and how they organize code.
explanation: Partials: files starting with _ (e<cod.g., _variables<cod.scss). <cod@import includes partials, combines into single CSS. Enables modular organization, reusability. Modern: use <cod@use/<cod@forward instead of <cod@import.

options.text: Partials: _filename<cod.scss; <cod@import includes them; enables modular organization

options.explanation: Incorrect. Still used, though @use is preferred.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which CSS properties trigger layout reflow? (Select all that apply)
content: Layout reflow is expensive. Identify CSS properties that trigger layout calculations and should be avoided in animations.
explanation: Properties that trigger reflow: width, height, top, left, margin, padding, border, display, position, float. These cause layout recalculation. Use transform/opacity for animations instead.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which CSS properties enable hardware acceleration for animations? (Select all that apply)
content: Hardware acceleration improves animation performance. Identify CSS properties that trigger GPU acceleration.
explanation: Properties that trigger GPU: transform (translate, scale, rotate), opacity, filter, will-change. These use compositor layer, avoid layout/paint. Avoid animating width, height, top, left (trigger layout).

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Which PostCSS plugins are commonly used in modern CSS workflows? (Select all that apply)
content: PostCSS is a powerful CSS tool. Identify commonly used PostCSS plugins and their purposes.
explanation: Common plugins: autoprefixer (adds vendor prefixes), cssnano (minification), postcss-preset-env (modern CSS), postcss-nested (nesting), postcss-import (imports). Essential for modern CSS workflows.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Mixins are deprecated
content: SASS provides mixins and functions. Explain the differences between mixins and functions and their use cases.
explanation: Mixins: generate CSS code blocks, can include properties, can take parameters, output CSS. Functions: return values, used in calculations, don't output CSS directly. Use mixins for reusable styles, functions for calculations.

options.text: Mixins: generate CSS blocks; Functions: return values for calculations

options.explanation: Incorrect. Functions return values, not CSS.
Incorrect. Mixins are still widely used.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: transition only works with JavaScript
content: Transitions and animations both create motion. Explain the differences and appropriate use cases for each.
explanation: transition: simple state changes (hover, focus), single property changes, automatic trigger. animation: complex sequences, multiple keyframes, programmatic control, loops. Use transition for simple changes, animation for complex sequences.

options.text: transition: simple state changes; animation: complex sequences with keyframes

options.explanation: Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Accessibility is crucial for animations. Explain how to respect user motion preferences and create accessible animations.
explanation: prefers-reduced-motion: user preference for less motion. Use <cod@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) to disable or simplify animations. Essential for vestibular disorders, motion sensitivity. Always provide reduced-motion alternative.

options.text: Use <cod@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) to disable/simplify animations; essential for accessibility

options.explanation: Incorrect. Can be handled with CSS media queries.
Incorrect. prefers-reduced-motion is essential for accessibility.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: SASS <cod@extend enables selector inheritance. Explain <cod@extend, its benefits, and common pitfalls.
explanation: <cod@extend: shares styles between selectors, creates selector groups. Advantages: DRY, maintains relationships. Issues: can create large selector groups, specificity issues, harder to debug. Use mixins for better control.

options.text: Shares styles between selectors; can create large selector groups; use mixins for better control

options.explanation: Incorrect. Mixins often provide better control.
Incorrect. @extend is still valid but use carefully.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Animation play state controls animation execution. Explain how to pause and resume animations dynamically.
explanation: animation-play-state: running (default, plays), paused (pauses animation). Can be toggled with <cod:hover, JavaScript, or media queries. Useful for interactive controls, accessibility (prefers-reduced-motion).

options.text: running: plays animation; paused: pauses animation; can be toggled dynamically

options.explanation: Incorrect. Can be controlled with CSS.
Incorrect. play-state is a standard property.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: CSS containment enables performance optimizations. Explain the contain property and its performance benefits.
explanation: contain: layout (isolates layout), paint (isolates paint), size (size depends only on self), style (isolates counters). Enables browser optimizations: skip layout/paint for contained elements, improves performance.

options.text: Isolates layout/paint/size; enables browser optimizations; improves rendering performance

options.explanation: Incorrect. contain is a modern performance feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: will-change hints to browser about upcoming changes. Explain proper usage and performance implications.
explanation: will-change: hints browser to optimize for property changes. Use sparingly: only when animation is about to start, remove after. Overuse causes memory issues. Don't use preemptively. Remove when animation ends.

options.text: Hints browser for optimization; use only when animation starts, remove after; overuse causes memory issues
options.explanation: Correct. will-change should be used judiciously.
Incorrect. will-change is a modern optimization feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Animation fill mode controls element state before/after animation. Explain fill-mode values and their behavior.
explanation: animation-fill-mode: none (default, no styles before/after), forwards (keeps final keyframe), backwards (applies first keyframe before start), both (forwards + backwards). Controls element appearance outside animation duration.

options.text: none: no styles; forwards: keeps final; backwards: applies first; both: forwards + backwards
options.explanation: Correct. Each value controls different timing.
Incorrect. fill-mode is a standard property.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Require media queries
content: CSS comparison functions enable flexible sizing. Explain min(), max(), and clamp() for responsive design.
explanation: min(a, b): returns smaller value (sets maximum). max(a, b): returns larger value (sets minimum). clamp(min, val, max): constrains between min and max. Enable responsive sizing without media queries. clamp() is most useful for fluid typography.

options.text: min(): maximum limit; max(): minimum limit; clamp(): value between min and max
options.explanation: Correct. Each function serves different comparison purposes.
Incorrect. They work with any CSS units.
Incorrect. They enable responsive sizing without media queries.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: min-width only works on mobile
content: Media query direction affects responsive strategy. Explain min-width vs max-width and mobile-first vs desktop-first.
explanation: min-width: applies when viewport >= value (mobile-first). max-width: applies when viewport <= value (desktop-first). Mobile-first (min-width) is preferred: progressive enhancement, better performance. Desktop-first (max-width) is legacy approach.

options.text: min-width: mobile-first (viewport >= X); max-width: desktop-first (viewport <= X)
options.explanation: Correct. min-width is for mobile-first approach.
Incorrect. They work in opposite directions.
Incorrect. min-width works on all devices.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Require JavaScript
content: Media elements need proper fitting. Explain object-fit and object-position for responsive media.
explanation: object-fit: how content fits (fill, contain, cover, none, scale-down). object-position: where content is positioned (like background-position). Essential for responsive images in fixed containers. Prevents distortion, enables cropping/centering.

options.text: object-fit: how content fits container; object-position: where content is positioned
options.explanation: Correct. They control different aspects of media display.
Incorrect. They work with img and video elements.
Incorrect. They are pure CSS properties.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: JavaScript resize handlers (not CSS-only)
content: Responsive images are crucial for performance. Identify CSS-only techniques for responsive images.

options.explanation: Correct. Picture element enables responsive images.
Correct. object-fit helps with responsive display.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: device-width (not a preference feature)
content: Media queries can detect user preferences. Identify features that enable preference-based styling.
explanation: prefers-color-scheme: dark/light mode. prefers-reduced-motion: motion sensitivity. prefers-contrast: contrast preferences. prefers-reduced-transparency: transparency preferences. These enable accessible, user-preference-aware designs.

options.explanation: Incorrect. device-width is for viewport size, not preferences.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires JavaScript
content: Layout shift hurts user experience. Explain how aspect-ratio prevents Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS).
explanation: aspect-ratio maintains width<cod:height ratio. Prevents layout shift when images/media load. Set aspect-ratio on container, image loads and fills. No height jump = no CLS. Essential for Core Web Vitals. Works with width or height, maintains ratio.

options.text: Maintains width<cod:height ratio; prevents layout shift when content loads; improves CLS

options.explanation: Incorrect. aspect-ratio works with any element.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Are deprecated
content: Modern viewport units account for browser UI. Explain dynamic and small viewport units vs standard units.
explanation: vw/vh: viewport size (can change with browser UI). dvw/dvh: dynamic viewport (accounts for browser UI changes). svw/svh: small viewport (minimum size, ignores browser UI). lvw/lvh: large viewport (maximum size). Use dvw/dvh for mobile where browser UI shows/hides.

options.text: dvw/dvh: dynamic (accounts for browser UI); svw/svh: small (minimum, ignores UI); vw/vh: standard
options.explanation: Correct. New units handle browser UI better.
Incorrect. They handle browser UI differently.
Incorrect. They're especially useful on mobile.
Incorrect. They're modern features for better mobile support.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Container queries work in all browsers
content: Container queries are a modern alternative to media queries. Explain when container queries are more appropriate.
explanation: Media queries: viewport-based (page-level). Container queries: container-based (component-level). Use container queries for reusable components that need to adapt to container size, not viewport. Better for component libraries, cards, widgets. Limited support (Chrome 105+, Safari 16+).

options.text: Container queries: component-level responsiveness; better for reusable components
options.explanation: Correct. Container queries enable component-level responsiveness.
Incorrect. Container queries solve different problems.

options.text: Container queries work in all browsers

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Fixed px values (not fluid)
content: Fluid typography scales smoothly. Identify CSS techniques that create fluid, responsive text sizing.
explanation: clamp() function (min, preferred, max), calc() with viewport units, vw/vh units, fluid typography formulas. clamp() is most common: clamp(1rem, 4vw, 2rem). Enables text that scales smoothly between breakpoints.

options.explanation: Correct. Viewport units enable fluid sizing.
Incorrect. Fixed pixels are not fluid.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS
